page.title: 02TURNERS HILL & CRAWLEY DOWN
page.content: Crawley Down and Turners Hill are villages in the{High Weald.}They are built on adjacent ridges dissected by the headwaters of three major rivers in south-east England; the{Ouse,}the {Medway}and the{Mole.}A mile to the west, in the valley of the Mole, lies the hamlet of{Rowfant.}The{geology}of the area is{Upper Tunbridge Wells Sand which has layers of sandstone and clay. In the past, the clay was used for making{bricks}and the sandstone was used as{building stone.}Also,{iron {ore}was{mined}and{smelted}in the district. Turners Hill is steep to the north and south and is the{highest place}in the area at 178m above sea level. Crawley Down, on a broad, level ridge, sloping to the east, is 129m at its highest point. The general impression of the area is of trees and pasture.
